bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, November 9, 1953

div1.p: Hench had hoped to write a formal report on the dedication of Camp Lazear, but asks Siler to accept his earlier informal description of the ceremony until he can write a report and illustrate it with photos.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, November 9, 1953
div1.opener:
November 9, 1953
Col. J. F. Siler
President, Walter Reed Memorial Association
1835 Eye Street N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I had hoped, long before this, to send to the Walter Reed Memorial As-
sociation something in the nature of a formal report of the dedication
of Camp Lazear and the memorial to Walter Reed and his associates in
Havana, December 3, 1952. I collected many clippings as well as photo-
graphs and other material and will, in time, write this report but
whether I can get it to you before the November meeting I cannot say.

Let me make this much of a report, that the Cuban Government put on a
very gracious ceremony and that they officially preserved the name Camp
Lazear and, as you probably know, presented varying degrees of the Finlay
Medal to the survivors of the experiments or to the main relatives of
the members of the Yellow Fever Commission. The ceremony was all that
one could desire.

I believe I sent you an informal description of the ceremony. Please
accept that as my formal report until such time as I can write it up
and illustrate it with photographs. It may be that I will go down to
Havana in January and I will let you know thereafter more of the uses
and condition of Camp Lazear.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
